title: SATs and Measuring Merit in College Admissions
description: Readers discuss a column by Ross Douthat about colleges no longer requiring SAT scores.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: What Gustavo Dudamel’s Recordings Reveal About His Conducting
description: The discography of the New York Philharmonic’s future music director suggests that he is an often agreeable maestro with a lot of work still to do.
content: Seven years ago, not long after Jaap van Zweden had been proclaimed the music director of the New York Philharmonic, I listened to every commercial recording of his that I could lay my hands on, to get a better sense of his conducting. I do not remember it exactly as a fun experience, when I have to remember it at all, nor one that flattered him that much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Pema Tseden, Pioneering Tibetan Filmmaker, Is Dead at 53
description: His films captured contemporary Tibetan life as Tibetans saw it, devoid of the stereotypes long associated with their homeland.
content: Pema Tseden, a filmmaker and author who presented an honest look at contemporary Tibetan life despite intense scrutiny from Chinese censors, died on Monday in Tibet. He was 53.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Asylum Debate Snarls Efforts to Forge an Immigration Deal in Congress
description: Despite hopes among some Democrats and Republicans that the expiration of strict pandemic-era border rules would force a compromise, bipartisan talks have sputtered.
content: A crush of asylum claims at the U.S.-Mexico border is complicating an already intractable immigration debate on Capitol Hill, pulling the two parties further apart and threatening to undermine what some lawmakers have viewed as the best hope in a decade for Congress to forge a comprehensive immigration deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Golden State Falls to Lakers, Ending Title Hopes and Starting Uncertain Future
description: Golden State isn’t used to getting eliminated this early in the playoffs. Now, it will face questions about how to sustain its run since 2015 as a top contender.
content: LOS ANGELES — Whoops, shouts, music and a rousing rendition of “Happy Birthday” were so loud inside the Lakers locker room that they could be heard out in the hallways. Outside Golden State’s locker room, there was silence, as those inside assessed what had gone so wrong this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: No Playing Ostrich With Trump
description: As Sun Tzu says, ‘Know the enemy.’
content: WASHINGTON — My brothers Michael and Martin attended baseball’s opening day at the old Griffith Stadium in April 1951, with the Senators (as our team was then called) playing the Yankees. President Harry Truman had been invited to throw out the first pitch, and the stadium erupted in boos; Truman had just fired the extremely popular Gen. Douglas MacArthur as commander of the Far East, and the crowd was irate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Place for Reactions and Solutions
description: Spencer Leach makes a snazzy New York Times puzzle debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — As someone who has been solving New York Times puzzles every day for decades, and explaining some of the most difficult ones for years in this column, I am always so impressed when a constructor debuts on a Saturday. It might be too sweeping a generalization to say that making a puzzle for more experienced solvers is more challenging than putting together a smooth Monday grid or an intricate Thursday one. Nevertheless, I love it when a constructor hits the scene with a tricky themeless, like this one from Spencer Leach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Meet this year’s Eurovision hosts.
description: The most well-known to American viewers is the Emmy Award-winning actress Hannah Waddingham, who appears on TV’s “Ted Lasso.”
content: Wherever you’re watching the Eurovision grand final, you’re about to see a lot of the show’s hosts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Miller
title: Why Some Companies Are Saying ‘Diversity and Belonging’ Instead of ‘Diversity and Inclusion’
description: The changing terminology reflects new thinking among some consultants, who say traditional D.E.I. strategies haven’t worked out as planned.
content: Woodward is a 153-year-old aerospace company that required its male employees to wear bow ties into the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Lawyer Who Fled to Cuba After Shooting Girlfriend Is Convicted of Murder
description: James Ray III, 60, was found guilty of killing Angela Bledsoe in the home they shared in Montclair, N.J.
content: NEWARK — James Ray III, a lawyer and former New York City police officer, was convicted on Friday of killing his girlfriend of nine years in the home they shared in an affluent suburb of New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Slava Zaitsev, Enduring Soviet-Era Fashion Designer, Dies at 85
description: He gave color, sparkle and opulence to a generation raised in drab Soviet gray and designed for pop stars, Olympic athletes, politicians and ballerinas.
content: Slava Zaitsev, an effervescent and enduring Soviet-era fashion designer, once called the “Red Dior” by the Western press, whose over-the-top theatrical creations and persona made him a go-to couturier at home, died on April 30 in Shchyolkovo, Russia. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: The Florida Man of Formula 1
description: Logan Sargeant is F1’s first full-time American driver since 2007. Can his sport make the leap from Monte Carlo to Miami with its soul intact?
content: Logan Sargeant, the only American driver in Formula 1, is zipping around the narrow streets of Baku, Azerbaijan, at roughly 200 miles an hour. His head bounces inside the cockpit as a wheel shudders over a rumble strip. It’s hard to hear over the banshee shriek of his V6 engine, carrying three times the horsepower of a run-of-the-mill Porsche Carrera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Announces Its Biggest Military Aid Package Yet for Ukraine
description: The nearly $3 billion package is part of an effort by both sides to reset rocky relations, which have become increasingly important to maintaining European unity in backing the war.
content: Germany on Saturday sent the strongest signal yet of its commitment to backing Ukraine in its battle against Russian occupiers, promising more tanks, armored vehicles and substantial air defense systems in its largest weapons package for Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: Despite the Primping, ‘The Cotillion’ Is Far From Flawless
description: Colette Robert’s play takes aim at antiquated rites of passage, and how they can promote classism, colorism and retrograde gender politics.
content: The enterprising president of the Harriet Holland Social Club just wants the cotillion to be successful. The floral centerpieces are in place, a band is onstage, and the draperies are neatly tucked in and tied. The debutantes are primped and primed. By night’s end, she hopes, these young women will set off into their bright futures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: The Heartbeat of Hawaii
description: The last king of Hawaii said, “Hula is the language of the heart, therefore the heartbeat of the Hawaiian people.”
content: King David Kalakaua, the last king to rule Hawaii before its constitutional monarchy was overthrown, revived many ancient Hawaiian practices, most notably hula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: When Packages Go Missing, Can Tenants Check the Surveillance Tapes?
description: Landlords should address security issues in their buildings where appropriate. But they’re not police officers.
content: Q: I am a property manager for a rental building in Midtown East. In recent months, there has been an increase in the disappearance of packages left by delivery workers in the unattended lobby. (Delivery people are buzzed in all day, so it’s hard to keep track of who is coming and going.) We have surveillance cameras in public spaces, but they are for the safety of our tenants, not to monitor packages. But tenants have been asking to see the video footage to investigate the missing packages. Am I allowed or obligated to share this footage with tenants? What are my responsibilities?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Moscatello
title: Welcome to the Era of Very Earnest Parenting
description: Millennials, guided by influencers like Dr. Becky and the women behind Big Little Feelings, are trying to deal with their children in a new way.
content: A second after the plastic shovel hit my son’s arm, the other boy’s mom was rushing toward the sandbox, a look of Can’t I relax for five seconds? on her face. I made my way over too — probably with the same expression — trying to signal that it was fine (my son was busy playing with some other germy, sandy toy and barely seemed to notice), but she was already on her knees, eye level with her son, speaking in language that many millennial parents would recognize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: An Erdogan Loss in Turkey Would Stir Relief in the West and Anxiety in Moscow
description: European leaders would be delighted to have “an easier Turkey,” while Russia could lose an important economic and diplomatic partnership should the Turkish leader lose power in Sunday’s elections.
content: Sunday’s presidential election in Turkey is being watched carefully in Western capitals, NATO headquarters and the Kremlin, with Turkey’s longtime mediating role in the complex and often vexing relations between the parties riding on the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff
title: ‘A Daily Game of Russian Roulette’: Homeless in San Diego
description: As a record number of people die on America’s streets, Abdul Curry fights to stay alive.
content: Laine Goettsch packed her emergency medical bag and drove into downtown San Diego to look for her favorite patient, afraid of what she might find. Sometimes, she saw Abdul Curry cleaning the sidewalks near his tent and dancing to a playlist of Ed Sheeran songs. Other times, she found him hypothermic in a wet sleeping bag and surrounded by people smoking fentanyl. And then there were the days when she couldn’t find him at all, and she continued searching for hours as she braced for a call from the hospital, the police or the medical examiner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Why Ron DeSantis Is Limping to the Starting Line
description: Mr. DeSantis and his allies are retooling his expected run for the White House after a series of missteps and miscalculations allowed Donald J. Trump to define the 2024 Republican race.
content: In November, Representative Byron Donalds scored a coveted speaking slot: introducing Gov. Ron DeSantis after a landslide re-election turned the swing state of Florida deep red. Standing onstage at a victory party for Mr. DeSantis in Tampa, Mr. Donalds praised him as “America’s governor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennie Coughlin
title: Road Races Look Different From the Back of the Pack
description: The distance is the same no matter when you finish, but slower runners find the race experience can vary a lot.
content: Latoya Shauntay Snell has run more than 200 races, and she knows where she will finish: near the back. So she expects to always be seeded in the last wave in multiwave races. But at the Brooklyn Half Marathon last month, she found herself in Wave 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Katharine Tramontana
title: She Never Wanted to Be a Mother. Now She’s Written a Book for Women Like Her.
description: Ruby Warrington, author of “Women Without Kids,” on her friendships with moms, her plans for the future and how she refers to herself.
content: Ruby Warrington has never wanted children. Not while she was growing up in England and not later in her life, a commitment that was tested by an unplanned and rare pregnancy — she was using an IUD at the time — when she was 23, shortly after she graduated from the London School of Fashion. She had an abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall and Maria Varenikova
title: Sweden Wins a Eurovision Song Contest That Showed Solidarity With Ukraine
description: After winning the competition last year, Ukraine should have been this year’s host, but Britain stepped in to help the war-torn nation.
content: The Eurovision Song Contest grand final, held in Liverpool, England, on Saturday, was meant to be Ukraine’s party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel and Islamic Jihad Agree to Cease-Fire After 5 days of Violence
description: Mediation efforts led by Egypt were expected to end fighting that has outlasted previous clashes between Israel and the militant group in Gaza.
content: Israel and the militant group Palestinian Islamic Jihad agreed to a cease-fire on Saturday, according to Egyptian negotiators, ending five days of violence in which 35 people were killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Kevin Draper
title: First Came the Sports Betting Boom. Now Comes the Backlash.
description: In many U.S. states and across the world, regulators are cracking down on the sports gambling industry, citing harm to the public and, in some cases, to athletes.
content: WASHINGTON — Legislators and regulators who began the headlong expansion of legalized gambling in the United States are now moving in spots nationwide to tighten oversight of the gambling industry, particularly as it relates to advertising that may reach underage bettors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: At Eurovision, Ukrainians Find Community Far From Home
description: This year, the competition is hosted by Liverpool, England, on behalf of Ukraine. A discounted ticket plan means thousands of displaced Ukrainians can attend.
content: This week, there were reminders round every street corner in Liverpool that this northern English city is hosting the Eurovision Song Contest as a stand-in for last year’s winning country, Ukraine, where war continues to rage more than a year after Russia’s full-scale invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Calgary’s New Mayor Says Her City Is More Than an Oil Town
description: Jyoti Gondek wants to prepare Alberta’s largest city for a future in which oil and gas are no longer a major part of the world’s energy mix.
content: With the recent oil price recovery, Calgary has awakened from a long economic slumber, and its new mayor wants to help the city reduce its dependency on oil by becoming a leader in new sources of energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Juan Arredondo
title: Inside the Last Old-School Seltzer Shop in New York
description: Brooklyn Seltzer Boys has a century-old carbonator and a museum with a spritzing station. Beat that, LaCroix.
content: A century ago, before it was called sparkling water or club soda, and before it was sold as LaCroix and Spindrift, it was called seltzer. No plastic bottles or aluminum cans magically appeared on grocery shelves. Instead, factories across New York City pumped fizzy water into heavy siphon bottles that were distributed by deliverymen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, May 6-12
description: A difficult dance for those seeking to rise to the week's toughest challenge.
content: This week, carioca — which is a dance resembling the samba, or the music for it — was the word least found by players of Spelling Bee, while black was the word most found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: I Know the Pressure of Being a Doctor. Motherhood Is Something Else.
description: A new mother squares her expectations with the reality of having a baby.
content: It should be the easiest, most natural thing in the world. Or so it seems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: India Struggles to Eradicate an Old Scourge: Witch Hunting
description: Once driven largely by superstition, the brutal practice is now often simply a tool to oppress women, in many cases violently.
content: They ushered the young woman into their home and closed the door behind her. Then the beating began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: North Carolina Governor Vetoes Abortion Ban but Faces Override
description: The Republican-led legislature has a supermajority that could be used to override the governor’s veto and enact the 12-week ban.
content: The governor of North Carolina, Roy Cooper, vetoed a ban on abortion that was passed by the state’s Republican-led legislature. The bill prohibited abortion past 12 weeks, with some exceptions for rape, incest or to preserve the life and health of the mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Orlow and Evan Jenkins
title: Inside the Big World of Small Objects
description: For over 40 years, Tom Bishop’s dollhouse miniatures show has been the gold standard for serious collectors and hobbyists alike.
content: CHICAGO — Moments before 10 a.m., a security guard thanked the crowd for being cooperative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: At Least One Dead as Tornado Strikes Gulf Coast of Texas
description: The storm in Port Isabel did “extensive damage” to several structures and left 10 people injured, with two of them in critical condition, officials said.
content: At least one person was killed and nearly a dozen hospitalized after a tornado struck an unincorporated Gulf Coast community in Texas on Saturday, damaging numerous structures and taking down power lines, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Trump’s Lesson for the Media and Ron DeSantis
description: What two groups — network producers and executives as well as rival Republican presidential candidates — can take away from the CNN town hall.
content: Just before the South Carolina Republican primary in 2012, CNN’s John King opened a presidential debate by asking Newt Gingrich what he probably considered a tough question, about Gingrich’s ex-wife’s claim that the former speaker of the House had once sought an open marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: 12 Million People Are Under a Heat Advisory in the Pacific Northwest
description: An area of high pressure will build a “heat dome” over the western United States and Canada, leading to potential record temperatures, forecasters said.
content: More than 12 million people are under a heat advisory in the Pacific Northwest as temperatures through the weekend are expected to climb nearly 20 degrees higher than normal, with the extreme weather extending into Canada as the country contends with dozens of wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: It’s May in Rome: A Time to Revere, and Fear, Fava Beans
description: Although favism, a blood disorder that can cause a violent reaction to fava beans, lurks throughout Italy, many Romans look forward to May, when the legumes are in season.
content: As hungry Italians at the Festival for the Fava Bean lined up in a field in the Roman countryside to order fava and pecorino cheese, fava and porchetta, cream of fava on top of pasta or simply brown bags loaded with fresh fava, the manager of an adjacent garden spoke of the witch-fingered legume with dread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Knicks Knocked Out of Playoffs in Game 6 Loss to Miami Heat
description: It was the first time the Knicks had been to the Eastern Conference semifinals in a decade.
content: MIAMI — A Knicks season that began with mild expectations and turned into what some fans called the team’s most exciting run in more than 20 years ended Friday night with a 96-92 loss to the Miami Heat in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference semifinals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Democrats Spar Over the ‘Prickly, Prickly Subject’ of Immigration
description: The end of a pandemic-era restriction on migrant arrivals has set off new arguments in the party over an issue that it often struggles to navigate.
content: The lifting of a pandemic-era restriction that turned away many migrants at the U.S. border has ignited fierce debates within the Democratic Party over immigration and border security, exposing raw intraparty divisions over an issue that Democrats often find difficult to navigate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason M. Bailey
title: The Mysteries of Zelda
description: Countless people find joy, frustration and discovery in video games.
content: Decades before the internet made physical video game guides obsolete, The Legend of Zelda came packaged with a foldable map that teased its mysteries.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 13, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 13, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about large health insurers and companies that are buying up primary care practices misstated the relationship between Kaiser Permanente, the health plan consortium, and its physician groups. Kaiser Permanente said it had exclusive contracts with doctors’ groups, but did not own them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: New York City Plans to House Migrant Families in Public School Gymnasium
description: The plan faced immediate criticism from a Brooklyn councilman, but a spokesman for the mayor said, “We are opening emergency shelters and respite centers daily, but we are out of space.”
content: As New York City officials scramble to find housing for an expected influx of migrants, the city is planning to house them in a stand-alone school gym in Coney Island, officials said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: When One Almond Gulps 3.2 Gallons of Water
description: If we don’t allocate water more sensibly in the West, Mother Nature will do it for us. And that will be ugly.
content: RIO VERDE FOOTHILLS, Ariz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Canada’s ‘Most Photographed House’ May Meet the Wrecking Ball
description: Municipal orders to tear down or fix the dilapidated 19th-century Ontario farmhouse have devastated photographers who see in it the faded grandeur of a bygone era.
content: Perched at the side of a country road near Lake Erie in southeastern Ontario, an uninhabited, partially collapsed 19th-century farmhouse cuts an eerily elegant figure against the wide-open sky and the corn, soybean and wheat fields that surround it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Kamensky
title: From ‘Front-Page Girls’ to Newsroom Leaders
description: “Undaunted,” Brooke Kroeger’s new history of women in journalism, tracks the victories, setbacks and pathbreaking careers that have marked the decades-long fight for gender parity in the field.
content: Raise your hand if you’ve heard of Anne O’Hare McCormick. I hadn’t, and as the director of Radcliffe’s Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America, which holds peerless collections documenting pioneers in print journalism, I could have, and definitely should have. Brooke Kroeger’s compendious and lively “Undaunted: How Women Changed American Journalism” introduced me to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: John Frankenheimer Pointed His Camera Toward the Things We Cannot Escape
description: In the film “Seconds,” he took on the darker side of the 1960s.
content: It’s been months since I’ve recommended a movie, so this weekend let me, well, recommend a movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kesslen
title: Gone Are ‘Daddy’ Days. These Are ‘Mother’ Times.
description: Online, practically every famous woman is “mother,” a term with deep ties to the L.G.B.T.Q. ballroom community.
content: To many people on the internet, the actress Toni Collette is known simply as “mother.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Jordan Neely Was on New York’s ‘Top 50’ List of Homeless People at Risk
description: Mr. Neely, who was killed by another subway rider, was on a watch list for a city task force that kept track of the New Yorkers of most concern.
content: For years before Jordan Neely, a mentally ill homeless man, was killed in the subway, the city had its eye on him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W. M. Akers
title: Deep-Sea Creatures of Bittersweet Orange and Metallic Opaline Green
description: In “The Bathysphere Book,” Brad Fox chronicles the fascinating Depression-era ocean explorations of William Beebe.
content: Consider the siphonophore. An inhabitant of the lightless ocean, it looks like a single organism, but is actually a collection of minute creatures, each with its own purpose, working in harmony to move, to eat, to stay alive. They seem impossible but they are real. In 1930 William Beebe was 3,000 feet underwater in a bathysphere, an early deep-sea submersible, when he spotted a huge one: a writhing 20-yard mass whose pale magenta shone impossibly against the absolute blackness of the water. As you can imagine, it made an impression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Praachi Raniwala
title: Lavish Indian Weddings Are Back and Bigger Than Ever
description: After a more intimate turn during the pandemic, some wealthy Indian couples are now sparing no expense when it comes to planning their extravagant, multiday celebrations.
content: Indian weddings can be elaborate occasions, often lasting several days. But a break from tradition because of the Covid-19 pandemic meant that intimate or at-home nuptials became the norm for many. Now, the grand Indian wedding is not just back, it’s bigger than ever for the couples with the means to host extravagant affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: A Defeat for Modi’s Party in South India Heartens His Rivals
description: An overturn in Karnataka is a morale boost for the beleaguered opposition Congress party. But defeating the B.J.P. nationally remains a long shot.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ruling party on Saturday lost its only state government in India’s relatively prosperous south, results from elections in Karnataka showed, in a boost to the otherwise struggling opposition ahead of general elections next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: New Play Looks for Dark Humor Beneath the Sarah Lawrence Sex Cult Ordeal
description: A small production that involves faculty and graduates largely mirrors Lawrence Ray’s yearslong exploitation of vulnerable students. Some of his victims object.
content: Carson Marie Earnest, a New York City actress, recently came across a casting call for a “darkly funny, cautionary play in two acts, based on the true story of Larry Ray and the ‘sex cult’ at Sarah Lawrence College.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Warns of ‘Sinister Forces’ Trying to Reverse Racial Progress
description: The president’s commencement address at Howard University, a historically Black institution, came as Democratic strategists have expressed concerns about muted enthusiasm for Mr. Biden among Black voters.
content: President Biden declared on Saturday that white supremacy is “the most dangerous terrorist threat to our homeland” and warned a predominantly Black audience that “sinister forces” embraced by his predecessor and putative challenger are trying to reverse generations of racial progress in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner and Sarah Kessler
title: Biden Wants Airlines to Pay Passengers for Delays. In Europe, they already do
description: The E.U.’s passenger rights law has changed how airlines schedule flights.
content: Rotten luck seems to follow Mattia Zenere, 31, on his travels lately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lela Nargi
title: Divorce Can Wreck a Woman’s Financial Future. Here’s How to Rebuild.
description: Women who have gone through a divorce often see their savings and retirement depleted. Building back means careful planning.
content: Twenty years ago, when I was pregnant with my daughter, a mom friend predicted my future: The baby will come and — from exhausted necessity — you and your husband will divide tasks, which will fall on either side of outdated gender lines. At the time, I smugly demurred, but eventually there was no denying she had been right. I was a freelance writer who took on the role of caring for our child and house; my husband, who had access to financial advisers and retirement funds through his university job, saw to our shared finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Zelensky Meets Pope and Meloni in Italy to Bolster Ukraine’s Support
description: The Ukrainian president’s talks with the pope and Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni came at a potentially pivotal moment in the war with Russia, as Kyiv’s forces make advances near the key city of Bakhmut.
content: Weeks after Pope Francis bewildered the Ukrainian government with talk of a secret peace mission, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met Francis in the Vatican on Saturday, part of a whirlwind visit to Rome that included talks with Italy’s president and Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, both of whom offered their full support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Native American Chief Standing Bear Is Honored on Postal Stamp
description: Chief Standing Bear’s lawsuit in 1879 ensured that Native Americans would be considered persons with inherent rights under the law.
content: Chief Standing Bear, whose 1879 lawsuit and celebrated “I Am a Man” courtroom speech led to the recognition of Native American legal rights, was honored on Friday with a Forever stamp featuring his portrait.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Gift to Mom: Eliminating Her Old Debt
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 13, 2023.
content: “You saved me $92,000, so this one is on Mom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Kyna Uwaeme
title: Biden Is Talking to Howard University Students. But Does He Speak to Them?
description: Conversations with students at the historically Black school reveal a more lukewarm support for the president than among their parents’ generation. Here’s what they have to say.
content: When Ethan Hayes, a senior at Howard University, talks to his mother about politics, they don’t always see eye to eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Dooce and Other ‘Mommy Blogs’ Deserve Credit for Shaping the Internet
description: BuzzFeed and Gawker weren’t the only brands that moved the discourse.
content: In the past few months, several internet giants have fallen. BuzzFeed News folded. Vice is headed for bankruptcy. It’s looking bleak for FiveThirtyEight. And with the recent publication of Ben Smith’s “Traffic: Genius, Rivalry, and Delusion in the Billion-Dollar Race to Go Viral,” there’s been a resurgence of chatter about Gawker Media, which went kaput in 2016. (I worked at Jezebel, which was under the Gawker Media umbrella, from 2007 to 2008.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Mack
title: Soft Pants: The Post-Pandemic Benefit That’s Here to Stay
description: Ditching “hard pants” is just another way that the pandemic has altered the fabric — literally — of our lives.
content: Less than three weeks into the March 2020 lockdowns in New York City, my boyfriend turned to me with a revelation he was having while in the snug living room that had become our co-working space, wine bar and prison chamber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Samantha Irby Knows How to Trick You Into Thinking She’s Cool
description: The author of the new book “Quietly Hostile” is a fan of listening to Paul Mooney records, rereading “Gone Girl” and watching guys arguing about sports.
content: Like many people, Samantha Irby went a little feral during the pandemic lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr and Noah Throop
title: Awaiting an Uncertain Fate as Title 42 Expires
description: A family is among the first to seek asylum in the United States after the lifting of a pandemic-era policy.
content: As the sun rose on Friday morning, Antonio, 51, was gathering his things and saying his goodbyes at a large migrant shelter on the outskirts of Tijuana, Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Alternate Endings
description: Buckle up and look both ways (!) while navigating Sid Sivakumar’s Sunday puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The Daughter Who Got the Government to Cancel Her Mother’s Debt
description: Susan Miskin retired from her teaching job in 2019 and didn’t think she’d ever pay off her student loans. Then, her only child stepped in.
content: “I am going to get my mother’s loans forgiven,” read the email that landed in my inbox 10 months ago. “So if by May, 2023, when I turn 28, you need a success story, feel free to reach out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Behind the Heartbeat of Hawaii
description: Hula is an ancient and often sacred dance that is indigenous to the islands.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Sammon
title: We’re Asking the Wrong Questions About the Trump Town Hall
description: Are our ideas of journalism so degraded that providing airtime to a candidate is tantamount to an endorsement?
content: As a former executive of Fox News, I never expected to write this: CNN performed a valuable journalistic service this week by hosting a spirited town hall with Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Grace Ashford
title: Lies, Charges and Questions Remaining in the George Santos Scandal
description: George Santos has told so many stories they can be hard to keep straight. We cataloged them, including major questions about his personal finances and his campaign fund-raising and spending.
content: George Santos has told so many stories they can be hard to keep straight. We cataloged them, including major questions about his personal finances and his campaign fund-raising and spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr, Noah Throop, Aline Corpus and Axel Boada
title: ‘That Fear Never Goes Away’: One Family Awaits a Decision on Asylum
description: Antonio and his family, who had been living in a Tijuana shelter for months while waiting for an appointment to seek asylum in the United States, are some of the first to be processed after the lifting of a pandemic-era policy.
content: Antonio and his family, who had been living in a Tijuana shelter for months while waiting for an appointment to seek asylum in the United States, are some of the first to be processed after the lifting of a pandemic-era policy.
source.name: The New York Times
